body: Perhaps we should split tutorials (more details) from how-to examples (shorter, very few comments) (see #1059)

issue.title: governance: public list of roles on sktime

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
based on some discussions, it's not easy to find out who does what on `sktime` - for instance, CC membership is on the CC repo, CoC membership is in the CoC, and core contributors are listed nowhere in particular (which makes that information not findable).

This PR remedies the problem of findability by adding a `ROLES.md` to the repository root, as a single source of truth.
I've filled it in to the best of my current knowledge.

body:
I want to take up this as

> Add page for community contributions/links for blogs posts, applications, etc.

Could you be more explicit here where and how to add this? Thanks
Hey @afzal442 - yes, I've created an issue with more details here: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/1313 - mostly ideas so far, open for other ideas!

issue.title: Governance changes: clearer timelines and conditions for decision making

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
Update with final state - based on iterations, some of the timelines and case distinctions have been removed. New diff:

Major changes:
* making concrete conditions for core developers becoming active or inactive
* making explicit that core developer approval for proposals must be by a core developer who is not the proposer
* clarified where approvals/rejections must be put (GitHub), spelling out conditions for accept/reject
* removed the gummi condition on "major change" (no definition, no decision maker who declares someting a "major change")
* added 10 days as a reasonable waiting period, then PR goes to tech meeting and gets a reviewer assigned
* clarified when STEPs are needed, and that it must contain a design (not just a wishlist)
* formulation about encouraging contributors "from groups underrepresented in the tech sector" added

---

For consideration in the 2021-07-05 CC meeting, I've drafted proposed changes to the governance guidelines that aim to make decision conditions for PR acceptance clearer and put clear timelines on decisions.

Major changes:
* making concrete conditions for core developers becoming active or inactive
* making explicit that core developer approval for proposals must be by a core developer who is not the proposer
* added lazy lazy approval for proposals made by core devs (new), so core dev PRs do not indefinitely lie around without approval - this is based on assumption that core devs know what they are doing
* clarified where approvals/rejections must be put
* replaced the gummi condition on "major change" (no definition, no decision maker who declares someting a "major change") with a clear rule on when sth is considered a "major change" - based on explicit core dev statement
* added timelines for core dev consideration and decision making - 3 work days for non-major change, 12 work days for major change, 25 work days for stage 3 vote (if needed)
* clarifying what happens if lazy consensus is found (was not stated) - then PR must be merged by a core dev
* clarified that STEP must contain at least high-level design

There's one other unrelated change to the sentence at the start, about welcoming people "who have experienced discrimination" in the past. I'm not sure it's a good idea do define groups by their suffering rather than self-stated labels or qualifiers, so I changed it to "groups underrepresented in the tech sector".

issue.title: Update docs (multiple minor fixes)

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
#### Reference Issues/PRs
Related to #1159 

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
* move file content to rst files in docs folder, keeping md files with links to website in root dir
* converts file in root dir to markdown (rst doesn't render correctly)
* Key documents are copied over and unchanged (governance, code of conduct)
* fixes broken cross-references in docs (contributing)
* add roles to website (based on PR #1296)
* uses sphinx extension `github_issues` to link to GitHub issues, PRs and users
* move STEP description to website, combining info from governance document and repository
* fixes sphinx warning by fixing missing data set export in init file for `load_acsf1`
